hero.p: A training and experimentation environment powered by real seismic events from official sources Perfect for students, developers, and technicians looking to learn by working with real-world data.

info.content_event: Access comprehensive information about seismic events, including magnitude, depth, coordinates, time, and location.
info.content_advanced: Query earthquakes by time range, location, magnitude interval, and distance radius to get exactly the data you need.
info.content_statistical: Generate customized statistics and summaries to analyze seismic activity over time or in specific regions.
info.content_easy: Seamlessly integrate earthquake data into dashboards, monitoring tools, GIS platforms, mobile apps, or educational projects.
info.description_p: Earthquakes are natural phenomena caused by a sudden release of energy in the Earth's crust, generating seismic waves. Understanding and monitoring them is crucial for risk management and scientific research. TerraQuake API is designed to provide reliable and accessible earthquake data through a modern and developer-friendly interface.
info.subdescription_p: Here's what you can do with it:

about.description_card_introduction: TerraQuake API is an open-source project designed to make seismic data more accessible, clear, and usable for developers, researchers, institutions, and communities. The goal is to provide a modern and simple interface to consult real-time earthquake information, promoting applications focused on safety and disaster prevention.
about.description_card_motivation: The project was born from the need for free and open tools that allow fast and reliable access to seismic data. By translating technical information into accessible APIs, anyone—from students to emergency app developers—can build innovative solutions to protect people and communities.
about.description_card_features: TerraQuake API provides access to up-to-date seismic data from official sources such as INGV, offering advanced filtering options by geographic location, magnitude, and time. The API returns JSON responses that are ready to be integrated into both web and mobile applications, complemented by clear documentation and developer-friendly support.
about.description_section_technologies: The backend of TerraQuake API is built with Node.js and Express.js, while MongoDB serves as the database. Key libraries such as Axios, Mongoose, dotenv, and bcryptjs are used to handle data and security efficiently. Environment management is supported with CORS and dotenv, and the project is hosted on platforms like Vercel or Render, depending on your preferred hosting solution.
about.description_section_licence: TerraQuake API is distributed under the AGPL-3.0 license. This means anyone can use, modify, and share the project freely, but any derivative works must also be released under the same license. The goal is to promote collaboration and ensure that improvements remain open and accessible to the community.
about.description_section_donations: If you would like to support the project, you can contribute via GitHub Sponsors or make voluntary donations. Every contribution helps maintain servers, improve the API, and ensure reliable service.
about.description_section_developer: TerraQuake API is developed by Gianluca Chiaravalloti, a geologist and full-stack web developer. The project combines scientific expertise with technology to create practical applications for seismic safety.
about.description_section_collaboration: TerraQuake API is proud to have a diverse, international team of 5 collaborators from around the world. Their contributions—from backend development to frontend enhancements and testing—help ensure the project is robust, reliable, and continuously improving. Working with developers across different countries brings unique perspectives, accelerates innovation, and strengthens the global impact of the project.
about.title: About TerraQuake API.
about.description: A focused platform built to translate raw seismic feeds into developer-friendly endpoints and actionable insights for safety, research, and education.

api_access.title: API Access for TerraQuake API.
api_access.description: TerraQuake API provides global and real-time earthquake data with filtering, geolocation queries, seismic depth analysis, magnitude thresholds, and more. Developers can use it to build dashboards, monitoring tools, smart-city alerts, or research visualizations.
api_access.subtitle: Getting Started
api_access.info: Currently, TerraQuake API is open for free usage and does **not** require an API key. In the coming months, authentication tokens will be introduced along with request limits and tiered access.
api_access.contact: If you'd like early researcher or enterprise access, contact us:
api_access.endpoint_recent: Recent earthquakes from the start of the year.
api_access.endpoint_depth: Earthquakes deeper than a given depth.
api_access.endpoint_eventid: Get a single earthquake by ID.
api_access.description_parameters_earthquakes: Most endpoints accept these common parameters for pagination and filtering:
api_access.info_startdate: Start date for range queries (required for /range-time)
api_access.info_enddate: End date for range queries (required for /range-time)
api_access.info_radius: Radius in km for location-based queries (optional)
api_access.javascript_example_earthquake: Fetch the 10 most recent earthquakes of the current year
api_access.python_example_earthquake: Fetch the 10 most recent earthquakes of the current year
api_access.info_stations: Retrieve all seismic monitoring stations (INGV network).
api_access.info_code: Retrieve a station by its station code.
api_access.info_geojson: Retrieve all stations formatted as GeoJSON for mapping tools.
api_access.info_closed: List stations that are no longer operational.
api_access.info_statistics: Provides aggregated information about the station network.
api_access.description_parameters_stations: These parameters are commonly used across station endpoints for pagination and filtering:
api_access.info_code_station: Filters results to a specific station code.
api_access.javascript_example_station: Fetch the first 20 seismic monitoring stations
api_access.python_example_station: Fetch the first 20 seismic monitoring stations
api_access.description_future_access: In the next release, API keys will be required and usage tiers will be introduced:

legend.description_ml: Based on the maximum amplitude of seismic waves recorded by local seismographs.
legend.notes_ml: The “classic” Richter scale. Still used for local and small events.
legend.description_mw: Calculated from the mechanical energy released (seismic moment).
legend.notes_mw: The modern standard scale; replaces Richter for large earthquakes.',
legend.description_mb: Uses P-waves recorded at distant stations.
legend.notes_mb: Used for deep or distant earthquakes.
legend.description_ms: Based on S or L waves recorded at large distances.
legend.description_md: Derived from the duration of the seismic signal.
legend.description_me: Calculated from the total radiated seismic energy.
legend.notes_me: Less common; useful for energy comparisons.
legend.description_mi: Empirical estimate based on observed effects (damage, perception).
legend.range_mi: From I to XII (MCS or Mercalli scale)
legend.notes_mi: Not a physical measure, but a perceptual one.
legend.description_mwd: A variant of MW using digital waveform inversion for distant events.
legend.notes_mwd: Used in modern global catalogs (e.g. USGS, INGV).

explore_data.title: Explore Data for TerraQuake API
explore_data.description: Explore and interact with real-time earthquake data. Visualize seismic events directly on the interactive map, and download the map for your own analysis. By clicking on “Switch to Tabular View”, you can access the tabulated section of recent seismic events, where each record includes the event date and time (UTC), magnitude, depth (km), latitude, longitude, and location. You can also search events by location, sort the table by date, and export the data in CSV format for further analysis or research. Stay informed and monitor global seismic activity with ease.
explore_data.description_legend: Magnitudes measure the energy released by an earthquake. Different scales are used depending on the type of waves recorded and the distance from the epicenter.

map.title: TerraQuake Map
map.description: Explore real-time earthquake epicenters plotted on the map. Zoom in and pan to analyze seismic global

show_info.list_info_three: Interactive map with zoom and pan
show_info.list_info_seven: Clear all markers with a button

table_earthquakes.title: Earthquake Data - Tabular View.
table_earthquakes.description: Explore the most recent seismic events recorded worldwide. Each entry includes the event date and time (UTC), magnitude, depth (km), latitude, longitude, and location. You can search events by location, sort the table by date, and export the data in CSV format for further analysis or research. Stay up to date with real-time earthquake information and monitor seismic activity with ease.

no_page.description: The page you are looking for does not exist

no_access.description: You do not have permission to access this area. This section is restricted to administrators only.
no_access.description_insufficient: Your account does not have the required administrator privileges to access this dashboard. If you believe this is an error, please contact your system administrator.

access_restricted.description: You need to be signed in to access this section. Please log in or create a new account to continue.

stations_data.title: Stations Data for TerraQuake API
stations_data.description: Explore and analyze data from global seismic monitoring stations. Visualize station locations on the interactive map, view key parameters such as station code, network, country, latitude, longitude, and operational status. By clicking on “Switch to Tabular View”, you can access a structured table containing detailed station information. You can also search stations by location or code, sort the table by network or country, and export the data in CSV format for research or analysis. Gain insights into the worldwide seismograph network and track real-time monitoring capabilities with ease.

table_view_stations.title: Stations Data - Tabular View
table_view_stations.description: Explore seismic monitoring stations from the INGV and global networks. Each record includes the station code, name, location coordinates, elevation, start date, and operational status. Search, sort, or export data in CSV format for analysis or research.

use_cases.title: Use Cases for TerraQuake API
use_cases.description: Use cases illustrate real-world scenarios in which the TerraQuake API can be applied. With fast and reliable access to seismic data, the API enables developers, researchers, and students to create advanced applications for seismic monitoring and analysis, as well as to practice directly with the provided endpoints.

docs_earthquakes.title: TerraQuake API Documentation.
docs_earthquakes.description: Programmatic access to global seismic event data — endpoints, parameters, examples, and best practices.
docs_earthquakes.authentication_description: Currently no authentication required — endpoints are public.
docs_earthquakes.subtitle_endpoints: Time, location, property and event-based queries.
docs_earthquakes.description_time_based: Earthquakes from Jan 1st of the current year up to today.
docs_earthquakes.support_region: Italian region name (case-insensitive). Supported regions: Abruzzo, Basilicata, Calabria, ... Lombardia.
docs_earthquakes.filter_depth: Filter by maximum depth (km). Depth classes: shallow 0–70, intermediate 70–300, deep 300+.
docs_earthquakes.filter_magnitude: Filter by magnitude ≥ value. Reference scales provided (ML, Mw, etc.).
docs_earthquakes.errors_response: Standard HTTP codes used. Error responses include `errors` array for validation details.
docs_earthquakes.examples_codes: Examples (each block has a Copy button):
docs_earthquakes.earthquakes_geojson: Each earthquake entry is a GeoJSON Feature. Important fields:
docs_earthquakes.report_issues: Report issues and request features on GitHub:
docs_earthquakes.author: Project lead: Dr. Gianluca Chiaravalloti — Web Developer & Geologist
